name: Duffin–Schaeffer theorem
summary: The Duffin–Schaeffer theorem is a result in number theory that provides a criterion for how well irrational numbers can be approximated by rational numbers with certain properties. It states that for a given function \(f(q)\), the inequality \(|x-a/q|<f(q)\) has infinitely many solutions for integers \(a\) and \(q\) with \(\gcd (a,q)=1\) for almost all real numbers \(x\) if and only if the series \(\sum _{q=1}^{\infty }\frac{\phi (q)f(q)}{q}\) diverges. This theorem generalizes Khinchin's theorem, particularly for
sequences of denominators. It was originally a conjecture proposed by R. J. Duffin and A. C. Schaeffer in 1941 and was proven by Dimitris Koukoulopoulos and James Maynard in 2019.
head: \(\sum _{q=1}^{\infty }\frac{\phi (q)\psi (q)}{q}\) diverges.
tail: The set of real numbers \(x\) for which \(|\!x-\frac{p}{q}\!|<\frac{\psi (q)}{q}\) has infinitely many coprime integer solutions \(p/q\) for almost all \(x\).
